Mapstr is a storage and a synchronization service that let users save and share their favorite places. Standing at the intersection of a commodity tool and a private social network, the app is used by over +200 thousands of users and contains millions of places, from local POIs to tailor-made locations.
My role as a UX Designer was to help improve user acquisition, drive engagement and build-up the community through the design, test and delivery of both inclusive and accessible interface solutions.
In this context, I led and mentored a team of 6 engineers, worked the end-to-end process â€” from design research to product iterations, and provided a rich documentation, including flows, prototypes and GUI specifications.

Friend manager and Notifications center concept for Android

Mapstr Design System - The results was the release of a powerful and accessible design system that included both iOS and Android components.

Design a system

When I started, the app was still close to its initial MVP â€” still beta on IOSâ€” So I build a simple UI kit to get going. When we released the app on Android I had to improve the framework to keep a cohesive experience accross our products. Also, as the team scaled, we had to develop a faster and yet a common language to work with.

Build a platform

Mapstr is aiming to build the default social platform to create, collect, and share places everywhere around the world. When we introduced user accounts, we knew that we reached a milestone â€” enabling users to interact within the app would have a huge impact on acquisition, which at that moment, was the bottom line lever to our companyâ€™s business growth.

I was in charge of the complete UX workflow, from the sign-up journey to the design, test and implementation of every account related features.
Each steps of the process required a deep focus on giving users the best way to access, control and manage their data â€” Location based inputs are a tricky thing, so a privacy by design approach was mandatory to create a trustworthy platform.

The outcomes were surprinsingly good, monthly active users (MAU) rised from 3.000 to +60.000 and we continue to receive a lot of great feedbacks.
